ache.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: if part of your body aches, you feel a continuous, but not very sharp pain there
ache.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: His feet were aching from standing so long.
ache.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: In everyday English, people usually say they have a headache, have (a) backache, have (a) stomach ache, or have (a) toothache rather than saying that their head, back, etc aches:
ache.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to want to do or have something very much
ache.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: He ached to reach out and hold her close.
ache.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to have a strong unhappy feeling
ache.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Tim’s heart was aching for her.
Sarah ached with sadness that her brother was so ill.
ache.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a continuous pain that is not sharp or very strong
ache.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: A dull ache throbbed at the back of David’s head.
Apart from the usual aches and pains, she felt all right.
